Issues.Title: fix(ivy): classes should not mess up matching for bound dir attributes
Issues.Body:
Previously, we had a bug where directive matching could fail if the directive
                              attribute was bound and followed a certain number of classes. This is because
                              in the matching logic, we were treating classes like normal attributes. We 
                              should instead be skipping classes in the attribute matching logic. Otherwise 
                              classes will match for directives with attribute selectors, and as we are 
                              iterating through them in twos (when they are stored as name-only, not in 
                              name-value pairs), it may throw off directive matching for any bound attributes 
                              that come after. This commit changes the directive matching logic to skip 
                              classes altogether.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): classes should not mess up matching for bound dir attributes" (#30002)

Issues.Title: fix(core): Fix Type<T> for strictFunctionTypes
Issues.Body:
See - https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/24428
tl;dr - When using `--strict` mode, `any` isn't a subtype of `string`
and thus the function doesn't match types.

Fixes #29905

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

Current definition for `Type<T>` uses `any[]` for the `new` function, however this doesn't work well with `strictFunctionTypes` because for example `new(foo:string)` isn't assignable because `any` isn't a subtype of string.

See - https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/24428

Issue Number: #29905


## What is the new behavior?

`Type<T>` now uses `never[]` which means we can't instantiate with `new` whatever we cast to `Type<T>` but now it should be assignable because `never` is a subtype of `string`

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): register NgModules with ids when compiled with AOT
Issues.Body:
This commit adds registration of AOT compiled NgModules that have 'id'
properties set in their metadata. Such modules have a call to
registerNgModuleType() emitted as part of compilation.

The JIT behavior of this code is already in place.

This is required for module loading systems (such as g3) which rely on
getModuleFactory().
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(ivy): register NgModules with ids when compiled with AOT" (#29980)

Issues.Title: build: publish ts-api-guardian rule in the npm package
Issues.Body:
With this change downstream users will no longer need to build ts-api-guardian from source as now the bazel rule is available in the npm package.

This can be used by installing ts-api-guardian as a devDependency and changing the load syntax from:
```
load("@angular//tools/ts-api-guardian:index.bzl", "ts_api_guardian_test")
```

to:
```
load("@npm_ts_api_guardian//:index.bzl", "ts_api_guardian_test")
```

**Note**: downstream users should also clean their `WORKSPACE` and remove the dependencies of angular workspace.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: publish ts-api-guardian rule in the npm package" (#29977)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure views created in constructors dont break queries
Issues.Body:
Previous to this change, we assumed embedded views could only be created after
their parent template node had completed processing. As a result, we only set
up query logic for containers after directives on the node were created.
However, this assumption didn't take into account the case where a directive
on a template node could create views in its constructor.

This commit fixes query logic to work with views created in constructors.
In that case, we need to create a query container before the new view is
rendered so query results in the view aren't lost. But since the query container
is created before directives have completed processing, we also have to ensure
that query results gathered later on the template node are inserted before that
query container. Otherwise, query results in embedded views will clobber query
results on template nodes.

This splice mode may be slightly slower than the normal matching for queries on
containers, but we should only fall back to this strategy in the edge case where
views are created in constructors. (We should encourage developers to create
views in ngOnInit instead).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): ensure views created in constructors dont break queries" (#29983)

Issues.Title: ci(docs-infra): increase wait for SW on all origins to avoid CI flakes
Issues.Body:
In #29953, the wait period for SW on localhost was increased to avoid CI flakes for the PWA score tests.

This commit expands the fix to non-localhost origins to avoid flakes in the `aio_monitoring` job, when CircleCI VMs/network are slow.
(For reference, example failures: [289127], [289238])

[289127]: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/289127
[289238]: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/289238
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci(docs-infra): increase wait for SW on all origins to avoid CI flakes" (#29988)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): allow TestBed.createComponent to create components in isolation
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, components created via TestBed.createComponent in the same test were placed into the same root context, which caused problems in conjunction with fixture.autoDetectChanges usage in the same test. Specifically, change detection was triggered immediately for created component (starting from the 2nd one) even if it was not required/desired. This commit makes Ivy and VE behavior consistent: now every component created via TestBed.createComponent is isolated from each other. Current solution uses host element id naming convention, which is not ideal, but helps avoid public API surface changes at this point (we might revisit this approach later).

Note: this commit also adds extra tests to verify bootstrap and change detection behavior in case of multiple components in `bootstrap` array in @NgModule, to make sure this behavior is aligned between Ivy and VE.

This PR resolves FW-1267.

## PR Type

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> On the Testing page the link "download example"(Sample app) will download a file named testing.zip which is nearly identical to the file specs.testing.zip from the link "download example"(Tests). 
It suppose to download a project without any test in it like in "Sample app" link but it download a complete project with all the tests instead.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> https://angular.io/guide/testing

### Reproduction Steps**
<!-- If applicable please list the steps to take to reproduce the issue -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:-->
Click on both "download example" link and go to src\app\demo of both, both contain demo.spec.ts and demo.testbed.spec.ts 
### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
<!-- If applicable please describe the difference between the expected and actual behavior after following the repro steps. -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:-->
testing.zip should not contain any *.spec.ts

### Anything else relevant?
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èPlease provide additional info if necessary. -->
If we go to "Sample App" and click the download button next to PROJECT, we will get a clean project without any *.spec.ts, which is the outcome that we want from the "download example" link
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Testing page "Sample app"(testing.zip) is wrong" (#29982)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure that super/sub classes can both update an animation binding in harmony
Issues.Body:
In ivy, because metadata is inherited, this may cause super and sub host bindings on
two components to update an animation binding in parallel. This patch ensures that
the animation transition code can handle this.

Jira-Issue: FW-1220
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ensure that super/sub classes can both update an animation binding in harmony" (#29978)

Issues.Title: build(docs-infra): increase build artifact size limit (and upgrade preview server to Debian 9)
Issues.Body:
This PR basically does 3 things (see individual commit messages for more details):

- **Increase build artifact size limit for preview server** (to unblock #29926).
- **Upgrade preview server docker image to Debian 9** (because some v8 sources were removed from Debian mirrors and because staying up-to-date is the right thing to do :grin:).
- **Pin versions of packages installed in preview server docker image** (to improve determinism).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build(docs-infra): increase build artifact size limit (and upgrade preview server to Debian 9)" (#29976)

Issues.Title: Clarify multiple downgradeModules example
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description I think the section about multiple downgradeModules needs more clarification and detail. The sample uses the Angular Compiler to dynamically compile separate modules to downgrade. This does not work in the CLI when doing AoT, so it would be good to include a more production ready sample. The error you see when running this sample is `Runtime compiler is not loaded`, which makes sense when doing AoT. However, the sample is not very practical if AoT is unsupported. The article in question can be found here: https://angular.io/api/upgrade/static/downgradeModule ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/api/upgrade/static/downgradeModule ### Reproduction Steps** Running the code from the sample ``` const downgradedNg2AModule = downgradeModule(async(extraProviders: StaticProvider[]) => { const rootInjector = await getRootInjector(extraProviders); const moduleAFactory = await rootInjector.get(Compiler).compileModuleAsync(Ng2AModule); return moduleAFactory.create(rootInjector); }); ``` ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment ### Browser info All browsers
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clarify multiple downgradeModules example" (#29975)

Issues.Title: Add experimentalImportFactories when migrating to loadChildren import syntax
Issues.Body:
The https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/14181 migration also needs to add `"experimentalImportFactories": true` to `angular.json` (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/13948) to make the import syntax supported in VE. 

The tsconfig file should also be updated to use `"module": "esnext"`, and a e2e test should be added to test the update works and an app with lazy routes will be updated and runs properly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add experimentalImportFactories when migrating to loadChildren import syntax" (#14218)

Issues.Body:
Also it prints the same error multiple times:

```
kamik@RED-X1C6 MINGW64 /d/sandbox/lazy-laoding-import (master)
$ ng build --aot
 10% building 3/3 modules 0 active 5
Date: 2019-04-18T14:42:38.478Z
Hash: 6e7545d3226e44a51fd5
Time: 7384ms
chunk {main} main-es2015.js, main-es2015.js.map (main) 628 bytes [initial] [rendered]
chunk {polyfills} polyfills-es2015.js, polyfills-es2015.js.map (polyfills) 2.8 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {runtime} runtime-es2015.js, runtime-es2015.js.map (runtime) 6.08 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {styles} styles-es2015.js, styles-es2015.js.map (styles) 16.3 kB [initial] [rendered]

ERROR in src\app\app.module.ts(14,26): Error during template compile of 'AppModule'
  Function expressions are not supported in decorators in 'ROUTES'
    'ROUTES' contains the error at src\app\app.routes.ts(5,29)
      Consider changing the function expression into an exported function.


Date: 2019-04-18T14:42:40.516Z
Hash: 384448c95268b8965133
Time: 9453ms
chunk {main} main-es5.js, main-es5.js.map (main) 625 bytes [initial] [rendered]
chunk {polyfills} polyfills-es5.js, polyfills-es5.js.map (polyfills) 358 kB [initial] [rendered]
chunk {runtime} runtime-es5.js, runtime-es5.js.map (runtime) 6.08 kB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {styles} styles-es5.js, styles-es5.js.map (styles) 16.3 kB [initial] [rendered]

ERROR in src\app\app.module.ts(14,26): Error during template compile of 'AppModule'
  Function expressions are not supported in decorators in 'ROUTES'
    'ROUTES' contains the error at src\app\app.routes.ts(5,29)
      Consider changing the function expression into an exported function.
```

proposal is to run them serially instead:
- fail if errors after the first one
- might reduce memory pressure since the GC could run on objects created and no longer referenced between the builds

Issues.Title: feat: Rename angular.json to workspace.json
Issues.Body:
# Rename angular.json to workspace.json

## Description

The Angular CLI/ Angular Devkit is a generic tool which is extensible to do almost anything. Having the workspace information stored in `angular.json` is a misnomer as it is possible to have non-Angular projects and builders defined there. 

## Describe the solution you'd like

With the new Workspace API, storage of the workspace configuration is abstracted. It would be great to support a more agnostic config file such as `workspace.json` or `projects.json`. 

Currently, folks can already build node apps or web-components apps in an Angular CLI workspace, but the naming of the configuration file deters folks from doing it.

One of the best things about the Angular community is how well we collaborate with other communities. Having the CLI to be more generic and used in those communities will reinforce this.

The `angular.json` file could be supported for backward compatibility. This would improve the experience for doing things outside of Angular within a workspace.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

An alternative could be creating a separate CLI altogether such as the NestJS CLI but it would be great to have 1 agnostic CLI since the Angular CLI is capable of doing both.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat: Rename angular.json to workspace.json" (#14204)

Issues.Title: Differential loading of polyfills does not work as expected
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ x ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```



### Description

According to the design docs, we should get es5 polyfills if the `target` in `tsconfig.json` is `es5` and `browserslist` points to es5 browsers. Currently, this does not seem to be the case.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

1. Use this browserslist:
```
> 0.5%

last 2 versions
Firefox ESR
not dead
IE 9-11
```

2. In `tsconfig.json`, set `target` to `es5`

3. `ng build --prod`

4. You will get those polyfills file:
```
chunk {2} polyfills.def630dd003427531b93.js (polyfills) 42.7 kB [initial] [rendered]
```

5. Update your `browserslist` so that it just contains `last 1 chrome version`

6. `ng build --prod`

7. You get the same polyfills file:
```
chunk {2} polyfills.def630dd003427531b93.js (polyfills) 42.7 kB [initial] [rendered]
```


## üî• Exception or Error

We should get a bigger polyfills file with corejs etc. in there first case where IE 9-11 is part of the browserslist.

## üåç Your Environment

- Windows 10
- Project was migrated to Angular 8-beta and CLI 8-beta

Issues.Title: [MatStepper] FormControlLike is not compatible with FormGroup
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
The stepControl attribute of the CdkStep/MatStep classes should be castable to/assignable from a FormGroup or FormArray.

#### What is the current behavior?
`Conversion of type 'FormControlLike' to type 'FormGroup' may be a mistake because neither type sufficiently overlaps with the other. If this was intentional, convert the expression to 'unknown' first.
Property 'controls' is missing in type 'FormControlLike'.`
Happens during compilation when trying to cast FormControlLike to a FormGroup.

```Type FormGroup is not assignable to type FormControlLike```
Is the warning shown in HTML files when trying to assign a FormGroup to the stepControl input of a MatStep.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Create a MatStepper with a FormGroup assigned to a stepControl of one of the MatSteps. To reproduce the compilation issue, try to cast the stepControl of one step into a FormGroup within a TypeScript function.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Material Version 7.3.7

Issues.Title: Virtual scroller doesn't disconnect DataSource when destroyed
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
If the cdkVirtualFor's data input is a DataSource, it should be disconnected upon directive's destruction.

#### What is the current behavior?
If the cdkVirtualFor's data input is a DataSource, it's never disconnected upon directive's destruction.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Just open this [stackblitz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fstackblitz.com%2Fedit%2Fangular-r7faxt&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGcIMIlM24RETc_INmfoYL9uhFhPg) and toggle virtual scroller in and out of the view multiple times. Check the console, and you'll only see the data source connection messages. It never gets disconnected. This will cause leaks if, for example, the data source subscribes to some service in order to fetch data from backend.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
The very last Angular Material v7.3.7.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
This is the piece of code, related to the data source disconnection logic:

![scroller](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34121107/56340795-b1b94b00-61bb-11e9-990a-b725cba2e726.png)

And here's a [link](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fangular%2Fmaterial2%2Fblob%2Fmaster%2Fsrc%2Fcdk%2Fscrolling%2Fvirtual-for-of.ts%23L269&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNHcGvIsWTegNK0YauLgEvv_i9KyUg) to this snippet. It's the only place where the data source gets disconnected. In other words, the data source is only disconnected if the data source changes. Hence the issue, mentioned above:  the disconnect() method isn't called upon directive's destruction.

If there's nothing I'm missing it should be easy to fix - the data source should be disconnected in cdkVirtualFor's **ngOnDestroy** method if the input is a DataSource.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Virtual scroller doesn't disconnect DataSource when destroyed" (#15855)

Issues.Title: [MatIcon] can not be embedded in SVGs
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug

#### What is the expected behavior?
MatIcon or equivalent should be able to be embedded via an ng-container tag so that SVG
icons render only SVG tags.

#### What is the current behavior?

Mat icons are always surrounded by a <mat-icon> tag which prevents svgIcons from rendering
when embedded in an svg.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

https://material2-issue-15045-ijytdc.stackblitz.io

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?

We are building a SVG based visualization library in Angular and I would rather not create my
own icon component. SVG icons should be embeddable in an SVG.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

All

#### Is there anything else we should know?

Th example has an inherited svg-icon component that I created. Because of some of the
internals of mat-icon I would rather material provide a fix instead of my app having to deal with breaking changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[MatIcon] can not be embedded in SVGs" (#15854)

Issues.Title: radio button checked when it shouldn't be
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
I have a set of radio buttons in a radio button group.  I try to set the 'checked' property based on a specific value. 

#### What is the current behavior?
Sometimes the radio button will be checked when it specifically shouldn't be.  Doesn't happen all the time.  I am wonder if this is a caching issue or possibly a bug?


#### What are the steps to reproduce?
<mat-radio-group class="radio-group" formControlName="answerId">
 <mat-radio-button (click)="captureAnswer(qAnswer)"  class="radio-button" 
                            *ngFor="let qAnswer of Question,let i = index" [value]="qAnswer.answer_id" checked="{{qAnswer.answered === 1}}" [name]="i">{{qAnswer.answer}}  (Trying to set checked property to:  {{qAnswer.answered}})
          </mat-radio-button>
        </mat-radio-group>


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
angular 7, material 7.3.7, windows 10, typescript 3.2.4, chrome
![radio-button-Capture2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1022238/56286908-8f9eca80-60e0-11e9-8192-bb7c582a41a4.PNG)
![radio-button-Capture2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1022238/56286919-988f9c00-60e0-11e9-848b-5ce493ef4a37.PNG)



#### Is there anything else we should know?
appreciate any help in advance

Issues.Title: MatMenu positioning wrong when scale != 100%
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
The MatMenu positions itself on the trigger as expected

#### What is the current behavior?
Normally it positions correctly, BUT if screen scaling is applied (either by Windows screen setting or by using Chrome scaling with CTRL+"+" or CTRL+"-") it positions itself quite randomly.
I debugged it a little bit and the viewPort ruler/rect variables are set correct (i.e. 1536x756 on a 1920x1080 resolution with 125% scaling; which is pretty standard on laptops), but when it sets the pixels on style attribute, it top and left position are scaled to 1920px.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7.2.13, Angular Material 7.2.2 and 7.3.7 (tried both), Windows 10, "Chrome 73.0.3683.103 (Official Build) (64-bit)", Typescript 3.1.6

#### Is there anything else we should know?
The menu component is builded dynamically (with ComponentFactoryResolver etc) and the same menu might be attached to multiple triggers positioned in different positions.
Also such triggers are inside foreignObjects created on a d3.js graph
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatMenu positioning wrong when scale != 100%" (#15845)

Issues.Title: refactor(sidenav): rework animation listeners to account for Ivy
Issues.Body:
Ivy equivalent of https://github.com/angular/material2/pull/15836.

In Ivy `host` objects are merged which means that the animation events will be bound twice to `MatSidenav`. These changes move them into `HostListener` so that they work both in ViewEngine and Ivy.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(sidenav): rework animation listeners to account for Ivy" (#15837)

Issues.Title: cdk-virtual-scroll: newly-rendered list items seem to inherit internal state from the _templateCache
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

New components rendered by `CdkVirtualForOf` are pristine by default.

#### What is the current behavior?

New components created by `CdkVirtualForOf` within the `<cdk-virtual-scroll-viewport>` inherit internal state of recycled views by default.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-virtual-scrolling-with-component-state

1. Click on *Data Item 3*
1. Scroll down
1. Observe *Data Item 12* is "active"
1. Scroll down
1. Observe *Data Item 23* is "active".
1. Scroll up
1. Observe *Data Item 10* is "active" (a different one, now)

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

```
Angular CLI: 7.3.8
Node: 11.12.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 7.2.12
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... http, language-service, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router
... service-worker

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.13.6
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.13.6
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.13.6
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.13.6
@angular-devkit/core              7.1.4
@angular-devkit/schematics        7.1.4
@angular/cdk                      7.3.7
@angular/cli                      7.3.8
@angular/pwa                      0.11.4
@ngtools/webpack                  7.3.6
@schematics/angular               7.1.4
@schematics/update                0.13.8
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.2.4
webpack                           4.29.0
```

- Microsoft Windows 10 Pro 10.0.17763 N/A Build 17763
- Chrome Version 73.0.3683.103 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- FireFox Developer Edition 67.0b9 (64-bit)

#### Is there anything else we should know?

Surely this is the very intent of [view recycling](https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/master/src/cdk/scrolling/scrolling.md#view-recycling), but it seems very strange that the default behaviour of `*cdkVirtualFor` is very different from `*ngFor`: my bound parameters changed, the data rendered via the `@Input()` changed, so why didn't the internal state reset?

It's more than _template_ caching, which most of us would take to mean the HTML: it caches whole components and internal state.

Obviously, setting `templateCacheSize: 0` fixes this problem.

Maybe simply highlighting this in the documentation might help, since you have to read between the lines to understand what's happening? Perhaps I'm the only one with this expectation. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "cdk-virtual-scroll: newly-rendered list items seem to inherit internal state from the _templateCache" (#15838)

Issues.Title: build: wire up dev-server for ivy demo-app
Issues.Body:
Currently everyone uses their own http-server in order to serve
the ivy demo-app. The issue is that most of these http-servers do
not support the HTML5 history API and therfore reloading examples
is not possible as it would result in the http-server directory listing.
